moves.2... e6 3. Nc3 Be7 4. cxd5 exd5 5. Bf4 c: Black finds white's dark square bishop too strongly placed on f4.
moves.7. Bxd6 Qxd6 8. e3: So white has a dark square pawn chain (f2 e3 d4) while black has a light square pawn chain (b7 c6 d5).
moves.8... Ne7 9. Bd3 Nd7 10. Nge2: 10 Bxh7 is no good, because of ...g6 11 Bxg6 Nxg6.
moves.10... h6: Black has to play this before castling kingside - otherwise white can capture the h7 pawn with check and escape.
moves.11. O-O O-O 12. a3 a5: Black looks for queenside space, especially for the bishop.
moves.13. Rad1 b6 14. e4: White has been planning this pawn break for a long time. Hence the moves Qc2, Nc3 and Bd3.
moves.15... Qb8 16. Ne2c3: White has a definite positional edge.
moves.16... Ba6: Again black swaps off a poorly placed bishop for a more active white bishop. However this means that the black rook will be stuck on a6 for a while. Another lost tempi.
moves.17. Bxa6 Rxa6 18. d5 Nxd5 19. Nxd5 cxd5: Simultaneously piling pressure on the d file and aiming at h6. White is interested in a sacrifice of the knight on f6, but the black knight on d7 obstructs this plan. (White wants to lose the knight to a pawn capture [not a knight capture] to leave h6 unguarded and the g file half open.)
moves.21... Nc5: Now white can unleash the kingside attack.
moves.28... f5: And black resigns (after making the move f5).

gameName: Knight sacrifice on f6 with check
